Award.AwardTitle: Developing and Deploying Flipped Classroom Resources for Electrical Engineering, Industrial Maintenance, and Renewable Energy Technicians

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award addresses a well-documented and growing workforce need for technicians educated in electronics, mechanics, hydraulics, and motor control in a way accessible to those already employed. The focus of this project is to develop online educational resources to support a flipped classroom approach to teaching technical subjects. The flipped classroom approach offers several advantages in that students can watch lectures at the time and place of their choosing and lecture content is always available for review. This allows a degree of flexibility for those with work and family obligations to attend a program of study. The benefits of the flipped classroom resources will be far reaching because they can be repurposed for other technical programs nationwide. The online lectures can be used to supplement or replace a textbook and cut down on student commute time and expense. The online resources allow non-traditional students with work and family obligations to maintain enrollment in a program of study.

Columbia Gorge Community College (CGCC) offers a Renewable Energy Technology program that prepares students to work in the field of renewable energy technology. Technicians use electrical and electronic theory to design, build, repair, calibrate, and modify components, circuitry, controls, and machinery and are responsible for operations, maintenance, and repair of equipment at generation and transmission facilities. The content is applicable to regionally significant renewable energy generation, electrical transmission, unmanned aerial surveillance manufacturing, industrial agriculture, and general industrial maintenance, and is adaptable to other programs and regions. Previous online material developed in cooperation with the NSF ATE Center CREATE has had an immediate impact on the CGCC's Renewable Energy Technology program by allowing an evening electronics lab. Incumbent workers can take advantage of the evening labs to expand and update skills while maintaining employment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In 2016 Columbia Gorge Community College (CGCC) was awarded a Small Grant for Institutions New to the ATE Program, titled, “Developing and Deploying Flipped Classroom Resources for Electrical Engineering, Industrial Maintenance, and Renewable Energy Technicians” (NSF DUE #1600434; $199,394). The project focused on developing online technical content for associated labs of the first year of an Electro-Mechanical Technology AAS. The Year Two summative external evaluation report prepared by The Sheinkopf Group states, “CGCC clearly accomplished, actually exceeded, all of the ambitious goals they had set. This is a project that is meeting a very specific need worldwide, and it can only continue to grow in the future as they add new courses and programs.”

 

The project resulted in the development of 258 online modules detailing introductory single phase AC circuit analysis, 3 phase AC circuit analysis, hydraulics, motor drives, proportional valves, timers, PLCs, and other first year electro-mechanical content. The content has received national attention as faculty members at many colleges are using the online materials in their classes and industrial and commercial users are training their employees using these resources.

 

As a result of adopting the flipped classroom format, enrollment in the Electro-Mechanical Technology program effectively doubled from a past average of 10-12 incoming students to a present average of 22-28 incoming students. US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE), Full Sail Brewing, Google, and Cardinal Glass have enrolled employees into the program, allowing them to remain employed while expanding their skills sets by attending the courses.

 

During the time span of the project, the YouTube channel being used to distribute the online content (https://www.youtube.com/user/bigbadtech) gained over 28,000 subscribers, and gathered over 3 million views. California and Oregon demonstrated the strongest viewership due to the close contacts CGCC has made with schools in these states; however, viewership in Texas, Florida, Illinois, and New York also increased. Instructors at Central Oregon Community College’s Industrial Maintenance program have adopted the flipped classroom resources for the hydraulics class and instructors at Clackamas Community College’s Electronics Engineering Technology program have adopted the flipped classroom resources for the basic electronics series of classes.

 

The flipped classroom resources will directly benefit students, instructors, and industries that make use of them. Delivering instruction online reduces student commute time and expense, and may be used to supplement or replace a textbook. The online resources allow non-traditional students with employment and family obligations to maintain enrollment in a program of study. Instructors at colleges and high schools, and employers seeking to develop their employees will benefit from the instructional materials developed through this grant. Additionally, the online resources serve as a recruitment tool for CGCC’s EM-Tech program and technical trades in general. Through an articulation agreement with Hood River, Sherman and Gilliam counties, high school students will be offered the opportunity to receive college credit for entry level courses. Individuals earning a EM-Tech AAS may continue their education at Oregon Institute of Technology in pursuit of a Bachelor’s Degree in Electrical Engineering. Career prospects will be enhanced for individuals with this core technical skill set.
